results.title: From Doric to Gothic
results.creator_credit: Andre Gillet, Marcel De Hubsch and Brandon Films
results.brief_description: This film reviews the development of architectural forms from the basic column and lintel construction of Greek temples, through the Roman basilica style and Romanesque churches to the groining and buttressing of Gothic cathedrals. The importance of development of arch and the later lightening of structural appearance is pointed out. The film makes use of animation, plans, scale models and actual scenes of buildings and exteriors, including some French cathedrals.

results.title: From creeping to walking
results.creator_credit: Arnold Gesell, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: Based on the work of Dr Arnold Gesell at the Yale Clinic of Child Development. Analyses mechanics of locomotion and the stages by which the infant gradually attains an upright, walking posture. Points out various stages where natural, unassisted infant action makes for best progress. Illustrates how attained abilities are related and how some are normal outgrowths of others.

results.title: From box kite to swing wing
results.brief_description: In 1914 the Australian Army started a flying school at Point Cook. The trainees took ten hours to learn to fly a Box Kite Plane. This video documents the history of air defence force planes from this humble beginning to their inclusion in World War I through to the sophisticated jet fighters that are the pride of the Royal Australian Air Force today.

results.title: From 5 to 7.30
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Read and American Temperance Society
results.brief_description: Shows the effect that drinking parents can have on their children. Joe is deeply disturbed when one of his schoolmates, because of his drinking, is involved in a motor car accident. His conviction is strengthened because he see the results of social drinking and “the cocktail hour” in his own home, and in that of his girl-friend. He seeks advice from his coach at school, and attends a lecture by Dr Andrew C. Ivy, which results in his decision to “leave it alone”.

results.title: Frogs and how they live
results.brief_description: Uses close-up photography toreveal key concepts about this familiar amphibian. The process of metamorphosis, hibernation and details of major body parts are also shown. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Frog went a-courtin'
results.brief_description: A 400 year old Scottish ballad, which tells the tale of the courtship of Mr Frog and Miss Mouse. Sung by John Langstaff, the song is repeated so the audience can join in by following the verses as they appear on the screen. Music by Arthur Kleiner and illustrated by Feodor Rojankovsky.

results.title: Frog went a-courtin'
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: The story of Mr. Frog and Miss Mousie, made from the illustrations of Feodor Rojankovsky, and sung by John Langstaff. The story is told twice, the second time the words are superimposed on the screen facilitating audience (children) participation.

results.title: Frog dreaming
results.creator_credit: Brian Trenchard-Smith, Barbi Taylor and Middle Reef Productions
results.brief_description: Something’s alive at the bottom of an uncharted pond, and the 10 year old adventurer Cody (Henry Thomas of ET) is determined to find it. The action of this children’s movie (involving Aboriginal magic) is set in a remote town in southern Australia. The real adventure is Trenchard-Smith’s rediscovery of boyhood, with all its inventiveness, innocence and independent fearless strength.

results.title: Frocks on the docks
results.creator_credit: Liz Orr, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Liz Orr talks about the dress she bought between curtain calls, the fundraiser for Heather Osland’s defence and the fight to keep the union strong on Melbourne’s docks.
